Dessert stall is quite small and you get to choose from a selection of waffle cones, taiyaki and/or mochi. The small taiyaki will get you 1 flavor and toppings while the regular would offer you 1-2 flavors. I opted for the regular taiyaki with a combination of matcha and black sesame.

The matcha itself is pretty mediocre, and is quite literally an icy soft serve. The black sesame is actually pretty good, and I think I'll get that instead next time. The taiyaki was filled with red bean which was yummy since the cone was warm.

Layout of the store was a bit inefficient and the lighting doesn't allow for good photos unfortunately. 

Overall Uji Time is just okay to me. If I'm paying $6-7 for a soft serve it better be damn good! But it didn't really live up to the hype and I definitely would not wait in line for this.
author: Chelsea W.

description: Would give it a 3.5 if yelp allowed for that. It's not worth waiting in line for. But if there is no line the ice cream is not bad. Got the matcha one with red bean filling. Would recommend the chocolate stick toppings as one of the free toppings.
author: Tom P.

description:
Got a small taiyaki cone($5.99) with matcha soft serve. As toppings, got matcha pocky sticks and kinako because they ran out of dango sadly. 

Soft serve was good. Didn't melt fast. Their special flavor was sweet purple potato which I wish I had gotten if I had seen it earlier. 

I've had better taiyaki cones so this one was alright. I think it was a little over cooked maybe?
author: Tricia Y.

description: I'm surprised by the long line but it is absolutely worth it. I ordered black sesame and it was so good! Green tea was just "expected", but black sesame is definitely a five star!
author: Lisa H.

description:
The tofu flavor is super weird, but my friend liked it so IDK.

There's always a line, but it moves fast thank goodness. They offer samples of the ice cream in case you want to try it before buying, but was pretty inefficient in the way they organize the responsibilities -- there's literally only one cashier and she's walking back and forth to the ice cream area to grab samples.. Surely there's a more efficient way of providing samples.

Anyways, it also always says the large fish taiyaki cake thing takes 1min to prep and the small takes 5min, but I think it only says that because people hate waiting and wouldn't wait for the small. We didn't mind and ordered the small anyways, and it was out within a minute. However, you can tell its already been out for a while. It was hard and not cakey whatsoever, whereas the large taiyakis are warm and easy to bite. 

This place sucks. Hopefully someone else opens a similar spot someplace else to do taiyaki cones with soft serve some justice.
author: Elvi T.

description: Delicious  mochi uce cream. Very busy on the weekends. The ice cream is delicious and the mochi is just as awesome.
author: Andrew M.

description:
You ever see something on Instagram and think oh I need to get that?  That's what happened with Uji Time Desserts, I was just searching food pics in San Francisco area since I was visiting soon and saw this fish cone, had to go get it!

So a few things about Uji Time Desserts, The taiyaki cone is made out of pancake/waffle batter and poured into a fish-shapped mold for each side, so if you are ordering the taiyaki cone, take note it takes about 10 to 15 minutes to make.  Yep there is a long line for a small shop, but honestly I didn't feel like I was in line for a super long time. If you get bored, talk to your fellow peeps in line and see if they are just as excited to get a taiyaki cone as you are haha.

I ordered a small taiyaki cone with matcha ice cream and it had a pocky stick, chocolate stick and some type of bread stick in it, and yes it was Instagram worthy. 

The taiykai cone is denser than a normal waffle cone, firmer than a pancake but softer than a waffle  and it's not on the sweet side, the matcha ice cream is a nice companion to the cone.    Another cool find in the Bay Area.
author: Monica O.

description:
i hadn't had japanese or asian-flavored soft serve in ages so i was ecstatic to see this business appear on yelp when i searched for ice cream and frozen treats in sf's japantown.

it was a little tricky to find, since i had to weave and wind my way thru the two japan center buildings, but i eventually found it...it wasn't hard to spot with the very long line of customers outside their front door.  i waited 10-15 minutes before it was my turn to order.

the cafe itself is not big, just the small kitchen, cashier, and a small counter where you could stand and enjoy your treat.  best option?  go outside the cafe and sit on the public benches (indoors) or go outdoors and sit in the peace plaza (if the weather permits).

i chose the matcha green tea and black sesame soft serve swirl, in a cup, and it was heavenly.  green tea and black sesame flavours were prominent in the thick, rich soft serve.  for $3.99, this was the right price point for the quality and quantity, esp since this was in san francisco.  i enjoyed every bite (and lick) of this frozen treat!

for a soft serve inside a taiyaki pancake (shaped like a fish), you'll pay a couple dollars more.  i think i'd come back again to try this concoction....soft serve inside a fish-shaped pancake!
author: Ellen L.

description:
Uji Time Dessert serves soft serve in interesting flavors such as matcha, tofu, and black sesame in a choice of waffle cones or taiyaki.

I came here with a friend on a Friday night after stopping by the supermarket for a drink and snacks. I opted for their regular sized taiyaki with 2 flavors of soft serve since I really wanted to try both their tofu and matcha flavors. The matcha flavor tastes similar to that of green tea ice cream as opposed to the matcha soft serves I've tasted in Japan. The tofu flavor ended up being my favorite of the two and tastes similar to soy milk I would get in Taiwan for breakfast. I like that the tofu flavor is not exceptionally sweet and instead focuses on its unique flavor.

The one thing that disappointed me was their taiyaki cone which really only resembles taiyaki in appearance. It was stupendously sweet and more closely resembled one of those very sweet hard waffles that come individually packed. I found it hard to taste and to enjoy the soft serve when the taiyaki cone was so overwhelming in sweetness. There is also some red bean in the lower half of the taiyaki cone, but I could barely taste it for the same reason. I would definitely go for their waffle cone on my next visit as I actually do enjoy their soft serve.
author: Joshua M.

description:
Did you even go to Japantown if you didn't take a photo of Taiyaki fish cones barfing up soft serve?

Miraculously there was no line and I had one of these cute IG-able desserts in hand 5min upon entering the plaza (though it was ~6:30pm on a rainy weekday). Soft serve flavors to choose from include Matcha Green Tea, Black Sesame, Tofu, and a rotating daily special. 

The Tofu flavor is reminiscent of sweetened soy milk. Delicious, albeit a little on the "did they add too much ice while making this?" side. And joking aside about the basic IG millennial mentality with the soft serve vessels, tbh I actually liked the Taiyaki fish cone more than the soft serve itself. The Taiyaki was crispy outside, chewy on the inside, and the fish tail is filled with a surprise red bean paste. Sorry not sorry for spoiling the surprise.

While $6.50 is rather steep, I like the Taiyaki too much and would opt for this option again. That being said, your girl is now inspired and taking recipe recs for homemade Taiyaki. HMU.
author: Deanna C.

description:
Best black sesame ice cream I've ever had!
The taiyakai cone is purely decorative, I'd say skip it if you prefer to eat it for the actual taste. The regular come is actually pretty good, and tastes great with the black sesame.
Long lines because they're making the taiyaki as you order, so it's fresh!
But if you order the regular cone, you'll get yours in a jiffy!
author: Angela A.

description:
Yeah,
Uji is different . . . but in a totally good way . . . I think.

Here's the thing, when you consider that two of their staple soft serves are Matcha and Black Sesame, you should just forget about ever finding something as trite and mundane (although very comforting and familiar) as vanilla or chocolate.

What really got me was their third flavor on the regulars: tofu.  I never really noticed tofu as having any real flavor (it is really more of a textural thing for me) but to then go so far as to make it one of your soft serve choices made me almost willing to try it.
                I mean
almost consider thinking about almost trying it.
                           maybe next time.
maybe.

I did try their latest seasonal flavor - miso pumpkin.  Again, different.  And again, in a good way.  Me thinks?  The familiar flavor of pumpkin first hits the palate and thoughts of pumpkin pie or pumpkin spice latte or pumpkin gelato start to flood my brain but then that requisite underlying sweet never fully materializes and instead gives way to a more qusai-savory taste.  I think I like it.  It's not exactly what I was expecting and was totally new and that's something I normally wouldn't say about soft serve.

And there enlies the reason why I am a fan: they're different, yeah they're different (you remember 2 Chainz don't ya?).  And it works.
I mean it's pretty evident by the steady line of people waiting to experience and enjoy these unique flavors.

Next time, I'm going with the taiyaki cone.

And with tofu soft serve.  Maybe.
Not sure.  But maybe.
Definitely maybe.
author: Dan B.

description:
My friend and I were walking around Japan Center on a Sunday afternoon and saw about 15-20 people in line for Uji Time Dessert. Despite the line, we were like "What the heck, we have nothing to do" and waited about 15 minutes until we ordered. The store itself is small, which explains why people have to wait in line outside the door.

Since we weren't that hungry, we each ordered a small Taiyaki cone w matcha soft serve. It was the perfect portion, the Taiyaki cone was fresh and warm, and the matcha was delicious! The small cone comes with one flavor and two toppings. For toppings, I chose pocky sticks. 

There was a longer wait time for the regular cones because of the time needed to make and then cool them. The regular size comes w two flavors, so it's a great option if you'd like to try another flavor like Black Sesame.
author: Sandy H.

description: Uji Time is no frills, but the ice cream is delicious. The shop is hidden in the Japantown mall, but it's worth the trip. We loved the matcha and sesame ice cream. The Taiyaki was yummy, but I'm not sure I would pay extra for it on every visit. We still dream about our ice cream at Uji Time and we will definitely return!
author: Emitom H.

description: It was a short wait to order and a short wait to get our order, but we had to wait outside b/c it was warm and stuffy inside. I ordered matcha and black sesame in a taiyaki cone. In other places, I've had a swirl mix, but here, the black sesame was on the bottom and the matcha was on the top, so I couldn't enjoy both flavors together or the taiyaki cone with the matcha. The ice cream itself was just okay. The taiyaki cone was cute and tasted just like a waffle, but it didn't have a consistent texture throughout. Some parts were soft and others were too crispy. Before I could even taste the taiyaki cone, the entire thing started falling apart at the seams, so I had to down the ice cream in a matter of seconds before it got all over my hands. It was, unfortunately, hard to enjoy my treat.
author: Effie D.

description:
I'd heard a lot about this place so I decided to check it out after eating some ramen in Japantown. Unfortunately, it didn't deliver.

There were only a few people inside and it was prime lunch time so that was a little weird that it wasn't busy but I wasn't going to complain about not having to wait long. My friend had been there before and he said you could sample the soft serve flavors before picking one, so we asked the lady at the register and she rudely redirected us to a different part of the little shop. My friend said he got the samples at the register before he ordered last time so that was confusing. Also, when we asked her about the seasonal flavor, she said there was none that day. 

When we went to the order pickup side we were told to go to for samples, the lady behind that counter called a previous customer's order out and told them the small taiyaki machine was broken, so they need to go place another order. The customers were confused and the lady wasn't having it. She was literally so rude about it that we just walked out without even sampling the flavors. 

I'm not sure how they have decent yelp ratings with such terrible customer service. Also, they should put up a sign or something if the taiyaki machine is broken because that's what people mainly go there for. 

I was excited to try this out but I was unimpressed and left completely underwhelmed.
author: Nikki R.

description:
Great place for delicious soft-served ice cream. Line can get quite long on weekends, holidays, or special events, maybe 20+ mins. Otherwise it's usually around 5-10 mins. Wait time after ordering is about 5 mins.

Although they also serve slushie drinks and mochi ice cream, the main draw is their soft-served ice cream. They only have 3 flavors(matcha, black sesame, and tofu) and one seasonal flavor, 2 types of cones(taiyaki and waffle), 2 types of fillings(nutella and red bean) and various toppings(red bean, kinako, matcha powder, matcha powder, pocky stick, poppy seeds, sprinkles, wafer stick, and French crepe). 

My go-to is usually a matcha flavor topped with red bean and sprinkles in a nutella filled taiyaki cone. The taiyaki cone isn't that impressive, but it's a slightly sweet pastry that's somewhat soft and crumbles easily in your mouth. Still, altogether it's a delicious treat.
author: Kevin N.

description: I absolutely love this place with all my heart. The presentation of it is so cute. The ice cream is so delicious and you can taste the flavors (green tea, black sesame, tofu). The cone shape fish is like a soft cone, not like normal ice cream cones which makes it stand out from any other ice cream shops. 10/10 would recommend :)
author: Kiana S.

description:
Exciting.

Long line. Not that long wait. Soft ice cream on a fish cookie. What more can you ask for?

The black sesame soft ice cream was heaven. As was the matcha ice cream. The fish cookie was ok, not bad.

The decor inside is pretty cool. Small space, but well decorated. The service is friendly.

Worth trying at least once!
author: Henry L.

description:
3.5 stars- Great soft serve, but I've had better taiyaki cones!

A regular sized taiyaki cone does come with red bean paste underneath your choice of two flavors of soft serve. (Menu is not very clear about whether red bean paste is included in all the taiyaki cones.) Regular size can be quite messy when each flavor begins to melt.

Soft serve
- Tofu flavor might be more accurately described as a fresh soymilk sorbet/soft serve. Really good if you like soymilk! Its also a bit lighter than the other soft serves.
- Sesame is real good! It is creamy but the black sesame flavor is strong as well. It even verges on being chocolately. 
- Charcoal coconut was the seasonal flavor and it was very subtle compared to the sesame soft serve. 

Taiyaki Cone
- It was both overcooked and undercooked since the top part of the cone is pretty thin compared to the bottom part of the cone (the tail of the fish). The batter could definitely be improved upon as well.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
The line was actually worth the wait! I struggle here and there waiting in line for something that actually ends up being terrible but I loved this!

Uji Time was pretty busy with a 20 minute line. Luckily, they offered samples to everyone in line to try the flavors so they could decide ahead of time. I ended up going with the seasonal Coconut Charcoal flavor and it was delicious! The wait time for mine was only about 2 minutes. It was really refreshing and light. Perfect for a warm afternoon. I didn't realize at the end of the cone there was red bean paste! A delicious little surprise. 

Not sure how often I'll come here (as per the line) but if you're in Japan Town and looking for a unique dessert, this is the place to go.
author: Adrianna L.

description: Icy ice cream, fish batter is ok not great, red bean not melted. Matcha flavor could be stronger. Cashier was indifferent
author: Kin C.

description:
Ujiiiiiii. I dream of your sweet matcha love and have insane craving at least once a damn week.

I am very into matcha right now. And it may not be just a phase. I bought matcha powder and everything.  Went to Uji for the first time and was waiting in the insanely long long long ass line but my sheeplike mentality compelled me to stay and wait. Ok just five more minute... Five more minute... For like 40 minutes. Anyways was interested in the taiyaki but after waiting for 40 minutes I was hypoglycemic so I just went with regular cone. (Quote 15+ min for small taiyaki and 30+ for the super one!)  

We got one tofu and one matcha. Both was absolutely amazing. 
Tofu is super refreshing. Its basically tofuhua in ice cream form. Or a light soymilk ice cream. How clever.  It taste so healthy but still super tasty. Usually you have to choose between health and taste XD 
Matcha is also delight. Melt very quickly. Nice green tea flavor. Addicting. I think about it weekly. 


Service is pretty fast. Line move quickly. Avoid coming here on festival or weekend though it's wayyyy too busy. 

Finally tried small taiyaki today though it said 5 minutes wait but it came out fast. Got matcha and soybean powder(kinako) because I panic and can't pick things. Matcha powder is definitely strong and bitter but went well with the soybean powder though yay although it didn't look super cool like everyone else's. Also my dummy face forgot my phone at home so no pictures :(( 

Anyways this is a good option for Japantown. Prices isn't too bad at all either. $4 for a cone is definitely fair.
author: Quynh Nhu D.

description:
Uji Time? Anytime!

FOOD: Come for the fish pastry made fresh (no fish added for Uji noobs--they are just shaped like fish, which are lucky in many Asian cultures) filled with froyo and delicately topped!

- Taiyaki (fish pastry) is fresh-made, which is key. My favorite touch is the red bean at the tail, ensuring that your froyo filling does not drip out at an inconvenient time. Reminiscent of Ici, who puts a dot of dark chocolate at the bottom to prevent ice cream from escaping their cones :).
- The froyo fillings are all delicious, and I love how unapologetically authentic they are (tofu, green tea, black sesame, and red bean among them). Can hope for a taro one day...
- Toppings are fun and look great on the froyo. Rolled wafer cookies, red bean, and other sweet dustings.

SERVICE: Order at the counter, pick up at the window. Cashier was patient and readily explained menu options. We didn't feel rushed though there was a long line before us (this we minded a bit more before we were at the front of the line :) ). 

AMBIANCE: This is a small space inside the Japantown mall (next to Daiso), which you can find with your nose thanks to the lovely scent of freshly baked taiyaki wafting out from the store. There is no space to sit inside the store, but the mall affords plenty if you are not a mobile eater. Love that you can watch the taiyaki being made fresh in the molds!
author: Helen W.

description:
I lucked out and came on a day with no line. Yay me!!!

Come for the fish cookie cone and soft serve! You can get one or two scoops and can try flavors before buying. 

I got sweet corn single scoop. It did not disappoint and there was red bean in the bottom! Mmmmm.

Give it a try if you can brave the line!
author: Mandi W.

description:
Located in the east side shopping center of Japan town. 

Order:
Small Taiyaki fish black sesame and you get 2 toppings. I picked matcha powder and Azuki (5.99) (perfect size if it's just you. 

Service:
The line is long, because they allow you to taste the flavors. I was torn between the tofu and the black sesame. Once you place your order, you get your fish pretty quickly. 

They also have a stamp rewards card.
author: Sochietta K.

description:
Came by on a weekend afternoon and the place was absolutely packed. Turns out the wait was only 10 minutes so not too shabby. I sampled both the matcha and black sesame flavor and opted for a small black sesame taiyaki which was more than plenty. The ice cream melts very quickly so you'll have to eat it quick. 

I loved the taiyaki cone and thought it was much tastier compared to a normal sugar cone. The cone is soft and warm and was a nice treat after finishing all the ice cream.
author: Edward W.

description:
Swung by this dessert shop Saturday night and there was about a 15 minute line as expected! The shop is small and outside of the main mall. There were a few flavors available: matcha tea, tofu, black seasame, and pumpkin (the seasonal flavor). All the flavors are meh in my opinion - the tofu was gross! The pumpkin was funky. Green tea - a-okay. The black sesame was probably the best flavor. They allow you to sample before you order so don't be afraid to ask. After I ordered, it took another 15 minutes to get the order (they were baking more fish cones). 

Overall an a-okay dessert. It tastes much better when the soft serve is eaten with the cone.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Weekday afternoon. Short line. Now 's my chance.

Counter servers are helpful and friendly when explaining the menu. Other people in line were also there for the first time. It's a small space, so luckily there are benches outside. My order was made quickly.

I sampled tofu soft serve, which was interesting, but chose a swirl of matcha and black sesame. Matcha is very true to the tea flavor, not sweet, and black sesame is good. I didn't order the taiyaki. I wish they offered more flavors. They sell quite a variety of ice cream mochi, which look good. Next time I'll try some. 

If you're in the area and there's no line, try it!
author: Carol W.

description:
I came on a Thursday evening and there was no line. I shared the regular Taiyaki with a friend and it was perfect for two people to share! We got the matcha and black sesame. Both flavors were very delicious and not overly sweet! There is also red bean paste on the bottom. However, I wish they put more effort in the Taiyaki. It seemed like they just bought it from the grocery store and put ice cream in it. I know it isn't there case but I wish the Taiyaki was more fresh? I think having it at least a little warm would be nice. 

It's kind of pricey so I recommend trying this with a friend. 

It's located on the same side as daiso on the first floor. (The "less popular" side of the plaza).
author: Joyce S.

description:
Uji Time was good, however after my encounter with this spot I think I'll stick to their Berkeley location. If you're asking about their desserts, their matcha green tea & black sesame ice cream is actually really good, and I actually highly recommend them! But personally for me the service was something left to be desired.

To the girl working by the pickup window, she alone is the reason why I would take an additional star off (I would have rated it a strong 4) and why I ended up leaving Uji Time annoyed. I can understand why the wait is so long now, and it's not only because of the time it takes to cook the Waffle cones (bc that does take time to cook) but because you're also gossiping and NOT DOING YOUR JOB.

(my little mini rant/experience after rating the food)

What I ordered-

A regular Matcha Green Tea & Black Sesame Ice Cream Taiyaki- Super cute presentation! The Matcha green tea flavor was definitely pronounced. Their Black Sesame Ice Cream was also really good, I like how it wasn't overly pronounced. The Taiyaki bottom was also really cute, and I appreciated how it didn't get soggy eating it. It was really warm & soft, and the red bean paste at the bottom was a nice touch! 5/5.

My friend also got a Matcha Green Tea cone sprinkled with Matcha powder and with Pocky sticks- And he really enjoyed it, however we did agree for an additional 50 cents per topping, the matcha powder didn't seem worth it. And also food for thought, Daiso is next door and they also have Pocky, and you could also buy your own pack for 1.50 & put even more on your cone! He said if he came back next time he'd pass on the toppings but he loved his cone, but he also agreed with me on how annoying the service was.

The also ran out of their tofu and their seasonal flavor (it was Piña Colada when I asked what it was at that time) , which was a little disappointing but their matcha green tea and black sesame ice cream were good.

(mini rant continued)

 I had first waited in line for about 10-15 minutes, and the cashier in the front was really sweet & took the orders promptly, so I didn't have issues there. I then waited near the pickup window along with other customers who were also waiting for their orders.

After waiting for about another additional 10-15 minutes or so, around 5 customers after me, a group of the pickup window's friends walked to the pickup window after paying for their ice cream. The worker then noticed them and & started talking to them while she was working, which I didn't have a problem with at first, but then I then heard her say that she was willing to streamline their orders so they could get served next, EVEN THOUGH ME AND 5 OTHER PEOPLE HAD WAITED IN FRONT OF HER FRIEND GROUP FIRST. She then proceeded to do her friends orders first (there were at least 4-5 of them), and then push orders that were there first to the back.

I just felt like it was really inconsiderate to gossip the minute she saw her friends walk through the door, AND ON TOP OF THAT streamline and do  their orders ahead of 6 other people who had ordered & waited fairly much longer than her friends did. 
I also noticed that her male coworker in the back was working solo, so the process of serving food became slower as she was distracted & wasn't being as productive. I ended up waiting an additional 15-20 minutes, waiting for her to finish her friends orders & have them leave before deciding to work on the orders that came before her friends. 

By the time my friend had gotten his cone, I had waited over an additional 20 minutes in the timing it took for the  IMMEDIATE NEXT ORDER after her friends left. By the time I got my cone I was fed up from waiting.

I sadly was really disappointed in the service here today. Though I don't regret getting Uji Time, (as it was delicious and I would totally recommend eating here, I'd give it a 4/5 for how much I loved the ice cream here), the service really annoyed me. I can only hope that they improve the service here and that noone else will have to wait as unnecessarily long as I did.
author: Allison O.

description:
Had Taiyaki come with matcha soft serve today. The cone is freshly made, and not over sweetened. You can also find same red bean paste at the bottom of the cone, which is a sweet surprise to me. Matcha ice cream is super tasty, and French crepe is my favorite topping.

Will definitely go back to try other flavor next time.
author: Wenjing Y.

description:
The line at Uji Time can be extremely daunting. The first time I came here, the boyfriend and I waited for a bit before we gave up and left. I was very disappointed. However, we were back in Japantown the same exact day and decided to give it another try. The second time around, the line was still long, but it moved at a much faster pace. But since we still ended up waiting 35-40 minutes, I must take a star away.

On another note, I thought the Taiyaki cone was pretty good. It was warm, soft and slightly chewy. I also liked the red beans on the bottom. I ordered the Small Taiyaki, Black Sesame with the Pocky and Wafer Stick. The coloring was beautiful, but the Black Sesame didn't have the strong flavoring I was hoping for.

Overall, I enjoyed my first time at Uji Time. Although the flavoring of the soft serve lacked, it was still tasty and definitely picture worthy. The wait can be super long and I can't exactly say the wait is worth it, but I do hope to return at least one more time and give the Tofu flavor a try!
author: Julia L.

description:
If you want soft serve, this is the place to go. If you want soft serve in a taiyaki cone, then you must come to uji! I got the black sesame and my bf got the matcha, and we just loved it ! I am excited to come back and try the tofu flavor. 

Lines here can get long but it does move quickly. So be patient as it is worth the wait. And plus standing burns calories which will make you feel a little less guilty for devouring your ice cream.
author: Wendy L.

description: I wanted to try the ice cream everyone kept walking around with and so I looked for the location. I loved it, it was my first time trying anything like it a lot. I had the tofu and black sesame it was really good and I tried the melon flavor too and that was definitely my favorite.
author: Adalys B.

description:
We were planning a trip to SF from Houston and this was one of the stops that I wanted to try out. This ice cream shop is located inside a plaza mall. My boyfriend stood in line (long line, small store) while I went to shop at Daiso. 

Review based solely on the ice cream.. It was amazing! I ordered the black sesame in a cup. It tasted really good! Very roasted sesame flavor,... and it came with the cutest spoon ever!
author: Nora C.

description:
I am HUGE fan of ice cream and matcha, and when I heard about this place, I was super excited! 

 I ordered the matcha soft serve in a cup, and it was pretty good. However, the soft serve wasn't as milky as I would have liked, but nonetheless it was decent for the $3.50 asking price. I also tried their tofu soft serve and it was super good; it tasted like tofu pudding at Hong Kong dessert places, which was interesting. 

I would recommend this place if you're in the area, but otherwise, I wouldn't make the trip just for it.
author: Sandra S.

description:
I happen to come here by accident when I noticed a group of people standing outside this small store. Uji is a name of a city in Kyoto renowned for their tea. 

The specialty here is their green tea ice cream and they came through! If you're a fan of Matcha like me, you need to come here. I ordered the large green tea ice cream in a Taiyaki. The matcha ice. Team is so smooth and creamy and not super sweet. At $6.99 for a regular, it was money well spent!
author: Micki M.

description: we drove to Japantown for some ujitime dessert black sesame + matcha swirl  and their limited July flavor lavender, which I got in a redbean-filled taiyaki cone with tofu soft serve swirl (I really wanted to try the tofu one and it was delish) topped with matcha pocky sticks and dango (mochi balls with a brown sugar syrup). Long lines but move quickly
author: Weich Y.

description:
I love matcha and black sesame flavors so of course I had to come and try the soft serve here! Came with a friend on a trip to the city and almost couldn't find it because it's a fairly small shop located in a shopping center. We went on a weekday, so luckily there was hardly a line. 

I ordered the Taiyaki Soft Cream cone (red bean filling, matcha soft serve) and although I liked it, I probably wouldn't be back anytime soon. Especially not if i had to wait in a long line. I've had better matcha soft serve at other places.
author: Carole Y.

description:
Pretty expensive but not sure where else I can get such good taiyaki!! This location is much better than the one in Berkeley.


I also hate the line too but it's definitely worth it!

My top flavors are Matcha and Black Sesame. The ice cream is rich in flavor and not too sweet.  I also love the taiyaki cone here. At other places, sometimes it's soggy or too stale but it's just right here.
author: Alicia L.

description:
Our friend brought us here during our visit to San Fran. Definitely worth trying! 

I don't really have any complaints about anything, but I still wouldn't say it's the best in comparison to similar places I've been to. Had the matcha and sesame flavour ice cream, both really good in taste. Also tried the frozen mochi. The one thing I will note is the desserts are pretty pricy for what you get, but again that is in comparison to other places I've been to.
author: Mellanie P.

description:
I had to try this place as it reminded me of Taiyaki in NYC. Around 9 PM on a Friday, there were only a few people in line ahead of us. After we received our cone, a huge line out the door! Guess you never know. #trendsetter

Staff is friendly and allowed us to try as many flavors as we wanted. There was a seasonal miso pumpkin, which was a bit too pumpkin for my liking, but I fell in love with the tofu sample. Also, TOFU, right?! Tofu soft serve. Amazing. It is a dream come true. I came with a friend so we ended up getting black sesame, but the tofu one reminded me of Asian soymilk. Sweet, delicious, homey. 

The black sesame was delish. With the fish cone, you get to add two toppings free of charge (you are paying an additional $2 for the fish cone - makes sense). We got red bean paste (inside the fish cone) and poppyseeds. Poppyseeds were a great call. It added a subtle crunch to the cream. 

Located in the Japantown mall, I'd probably come back if I was eating around the area. Let's be real, the location isn't great. You get your fish cone, you sit in the benches outside the shop, surrounded by a dimly lit and run-down mall vibes.
author: Vickie Z.

description: Taiyaki ~ Nutella lined, matcha soft serve filled, with azuki and chocolate sticks on top  Traditionally, taiyaki is a waffle-like dessert filled with red bean but it has since evolved to become bigger and sweeter than ever! My mom and I are in SF this weekend and she was craving taiyaki. This isn't quite the childhood dessert she remembered, but I'm pretty happy about it!!!
author: Emily Y.

description:
Boyfriend and I swung by around 4:15 PM on a Saturday afternoon and this place was poppin'! It was around a 20 minute wait but the line moves quickly so it isn't too bad. You can smell the heavenly scent of taiyaki as soon as you enter the mall; how can you resist getting one at that point? 

We got a Regular Taiyaki Cone with Black Sesame and Matcha swirl. We probably should have got the smaller size because HOLY.. I've never seen such a massive taiyaki before. The soft serve is absolutely delicious though. You can taste the nuttiness of the toasted Black Sesame and the slight earthy bitterness of Matcha. However the taiyaki itself wasn't that scrumptious; it was very thick, quite flavorless, and rather dry. Perhaps it would have been yummier if it came with a custard filling rather than a red bean filling. 

Overall I would probably come again but definitely will opt for the regular cone instead of a taiyaki (but they are so adorable and picture-worthy).
author: Sylvia L.

description:
The line can be pretty long and crazy on weekend. It took me around 40 minutes before I get to order. Their service is pretty good and they are friendly too!

I am a big fan of Matcha! So I ordered a Deluxe Matcha + Sesame soft serve + Matcha sprinkles + dango. I waited for 20 mins before my order is ready. 

The wait is definitely worth it. The matcha taste like the original green tea ( definitely doesn't taste anything like matcha syrup). The black sesame taste really good too! The dango is a little hard to bite -- wish it's more soft!

I will definitely come back for other flavors. They have tofu & seasonal flavor too. Remember to stamp your reward card for every taiyaki purchase!
author: Evelin F.

description:
Got black sesame ice cream in the waffle cone because I love black sesame. The ice cream exceeded expectations when I started eating it. The  black sesame added a nice grainy texture to the ice in the ice cream. Also the sweetness didn't overwhelm me. It was a true delight to have. 

There was basically no line at 8 pm so I recommend coming near close time because otherwise, the line can get a little tiresome.
author: Nathan C.

description:
I'm so bummed. I get it - a lot of the appeal of Uji is the novelty of the taiyaki cone. That being said, if you're paying $7.50 for soft ice cream, it could at least be good. However, the ice cream here was mostly just ice swirled around in a dollop of cream. The flavor was mediocre at best, and at the end of the day, while the cone was good, it was not worth $7.50. I personally thought the black sesame was much better than the matcha, but that was probably because the half that was with black sesame was eaten with cone. 

On top of that, you can not wear nice clothing when you get one of these. I've been told that these are really messy to eat - that is an understatement. I'm a pretty neat her, but the moment I took a bite out of the come itself, I had a torrent of melted black sesame goop running down my hand, shirt, pants, and bag.

Thankfully, I did not have to wait in line as I got there right as it opened on a Wednesday. That being said, if you're looking for good ice cream and not the Instagram photo, go elsewhere. You will get an overpriced, icy mess and a nice photo here.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Super Popular Berkeley dessert spot Uji Time is now in SF.  The Japantown location is perfect and on a weekend, waits were about 30 minutes which I've heard is better than Berkeley. 

The draw is both the ice cream flavors (Matcha, Sesame, soy) and the Taiyaki cones which are perfect for IG.  Because we have Matcha Love that serves black Sesame and green Matcha ice cream in waffle cones in San Jose and there is never a line, I don't quite understand the fuss here but I had to try.  My order:

Deluxe Taiyaki Cone $7.99.  The deluxe and regular pricing are a bit of a steep price increase from the regular waffle cone ($3.99) but I figured I had to try.  The regular Taiyaki Cone ($5.99) comes with a lining of adzuki beans (yay!) as well as the option to choose two ice from flavors (yay!).  The deluxe comes with the choice of two toppings but they're really making a killing with the $2 price increase because we got a pocky stick and a Matcha stick.  Other high margin topping choices include sprinkles, green Matcha powder, etc. 

Overall, I enjoyed my dessert. It's quite filling and I liked having two ice cream flavors.  The Taiyaki Cone was tasty as well almost like a cake dough and nicely lined with Adzuki beans.  While I wouldn't wait too long again, it is worth trying and next time I'll just get a regular. (The small are a deal and probably enough for 1 person but include an additional 30 minute wait time beyond a regular Taiyaki Cone). 

Uji Time accepts credit cards including Amex.
author: Randy F.

description:
Located in the east mall of japan center. Once I entered the mall I was hit with a strong aroma of custard. I thought it would be crepes or some sort but nope it was the taiyaki at Uji. We saw a massive long line around 2 pm so we resisted the temptation and decided to come back after dinner instead. We passed by a few times between 2 pm and 730 pm and saw there were moments of no customers but most of the time there was a long line. Lo and behold when we came after dinner there was a long line. 

We took a long time debating which ice cream flavor to get with the taiyaki: black sesame, tofu, or their seasonal coconut ash (they also had matcha but we eliminated that one). At one point a staff member came out serving tofu ice cream samples but ran out before it got to us. Luckily when it was our turn to order we asked to try some samples and our server obliged. Coconut ash didn't really taste like coconut and it was too bland. Tofu tasted like the tofufa (sweet tofu pudding). We ordered a regular sized taiyaki with tofu and black sesame flavor. They put some red bean paste inside at the bottom before swirling black sesame into the taiyaki. Then they cut off some of the black sesame and swirled tofu onto the taiyaki. 

I'm not sure how I feel about the layering (there's pros and cons to it). The ice cream flavors were alright nothing wow. The taiyaki was very fragrant but not served warm to us. 

A long wait time to order and receiving the order. But friendly staff and the overall taste is decent.
author: Melody C.

description:
This place was soo good! I came here on a Sunday around 1 pm and saw a mini line, and decided to try it out. I got the large taiyaki with azuki bean filling, matcha and black sesame ice cream and it was bomb!!!! The ice cream was a perfect sweetest and the taiyaki itself was not too cripsy and not too soft with just the right amount of sugar as well. (I tend to not like things super sweet.) I highly highly recommend coming to this place. 

Just a note as I was leaving to shop I saw that the line got even longer, so expect a wait (shouldn't be over 15 minutes) when you come here. Also there's no chairs or anything, but there are plenty of benches scattered around Japan Town east mall that u can sit at. 

If you are a matcha/black sesame ice cream lover seriously come here!!!
author: Ann T.

description:
The first taiyaki ice cream shop in the Bay Area. I hesitated to wait in the massive long line during the Cherry Blossom Festival but I eventually did at the end of the day.  I had to try it because I love taiyaki and it's worth trying since I don't come to San Francisco that often.

The line was shorter than during the day. Wait time was about 30 min. They ran out of Cherry Blossom ice cream and I resorted to the 1/2 matcha and 1/2 tofu. Try two flavors at once. The matcha was better than the tofu. Tofu tasted like tofu but it reminded me of a potato dessert. It wasn't my cup of tea.  I ate the taiyaki shell which had the Nutella at the bottom.  I wish the Nutella was actually spread around the inner shell of the taiyaki so it can blend w/ the tofu flavor.

If Uji Time has new flavors than the 3 flavors they have now, I will come back again when I'm in Japantown.
author: Miriam T.

description:
Very different. If you like unique, this is the place for you.

My family and I hadn't been to Japantown in a few months and when we went this time, there was this new ice cream shop that had greet tea ice cream! It must have been a brand new hot spot because the line was huge. I appreciated how they kept the line entertained by feeding us free samples! They fed us tofu ice cream...I'm not sure if I should be amazed or confused. 

My dad was particularly interested in the cone shaped like a fish and made of pancake material. I ordered the matcha ice cream and my dad got a blend of mocha and coconut ice cream, but the coconut was black. Although it was tasty for a few minutes, the portion was too big so I got tired of the flavor really fast and couldn't finish it.

I would say it's interesting and unique, but I wound't wait in line for 10 minutes to buy this ice cream. If you're into different flavors of ice cream and are sort of artsy when it comes to your food, this is definitely the place for you!
author: Laura D.

description:
We happened to come here because my sister wanted this taiyaki ice cream. This is our last stop before we heading home. We parked inside the mall, and came out from lift which close by Uji. The line was pretty long. My hubby went for line once see the long line. We waited maybe 45-60 minutes for us to get inside the shop and place order.

We shared one deluxe taiyaki soft cream cone with 2 toppings. We chose black sesame and matcha for ice cream, while toppings we had were matcha powder and kinako. The wait for order to get ready maybe 10-15 minutes. Once we had our taiyaki ice cream, we were excited to take photo and eat it. 

Their taiyaki ice cream is really delicious! It's worth to wait. The matcha and black sesame ice cream taste were so authentic and texture also firm. They baked taiyaki cone with right recipe and feel crunchy when biting it. I didn't feel soft on cone when biting it.

You can ask for stamp card also. They stamp on card for how many cones you buy.
author: Jaane F.

description:
Japantown has become an ice cream Mecca. While lots of people are lining up for the unique Dragon's Breath (at Chocolate Chair), others prefer to wait for taiyaki (soft serve ice cream served in a fish cone) at Uji Time.

I've tried both, and for my time spent lining up with strangers, I'd much rather wait in the line at Uji. The soft serve ice cream is actually good, although it comes in limited flavors: matcha, tofu, black sesame and a seasonal flavor. When I came here, the seasonal flavor was sweet corn, which, on the positive side, was at least sweeter than tofu. For me, its matcha and black sesame all the way. You can get two flavors. Both taste delicious down to the cone, and of coarse I had to get a few pocky and some sprinkles for good measure.

The ice cream tastes good and the cones are gorgeous and are being made fresh. At the bottom of my fish cone, a little treasure of red bean paste.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Go to Sophie's Crepes in the other building for better tasting japanese dessert and asian ice cream.

The soft serve flavors overly sweet with the icy texture of a half-melted snow cone. Taiyaki is the worst alternative to waffle cone and tastes like a playdo hot pocket.

Only redeeming thing about this place is the tofu soft serve that is somewhat interesting and tastes like soymilk ice cream, until you take more than 3 bites and the half-melted snow cone texture triggers your gag reflex.

This is also the place where you can be stoopid and pay $50c to add shit like a pocky stick to make your instagram pic more basic.
author: Tian Q.

description:
After a ramen dinner nearby it seemed a shame to go home without dessert! So we headed over to Uji Time for a small black sesame in taiyaki "cone". Ask for a cup to put this in. That way you can see the taiyaki (for those Instagram photos), eat the taiyaki at the same time as the ice cream, and also less messy.

The taiyaki was okay. Not crispy on the outside, mostly soft but stuffed with red bean paste in the tail. Black sesame ice cream was nice and nutty, not too sweet. We got ours with poky and chocolate sticks.

A fun and yum way to end the evening.

PS If you like tofu pudding you'll love the tofu soft serve. Sadly I couldn't convince hubby of this flavor.
author: Jean K.

description:
Cute place to get dessert in Japantown! I came by on a weekday night around 8 and there was no line. Score! We sat outside on the benches, and watched the line grow longer and longer, so it seems like the wait time can vary. 

Tip. You can go to the pickup area and ask for samples of the soft serve. I tried the tofu and the black sesame. The tofu flavor is really mild. You only get a hint of the soy flavor. The black sesame had a really nice nutty flavor. 

I got the small taiyaki ($5.99) with black sesame ice cream. The small taiyaki comes with 2 toppings. I chose red bean and pocky sticks. The small was plenty. I couldn't finish the whole thing. Tbh, I wanted to try Uji Time because it looked cute. I assumed it wouldn't taste as  good as it looks, but I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the fish cone itself tasted pretty good.
author: Kim W.

description:
The matcha soft serve is so freakin' good. Also, can I just give a shout out to the workers who pile on the ice cream swirl after swirl without it toppling over? Impressive. But also to me, that means it's too much and I can never even finish a small serving in a cup :( 

They only offer four soft serve flavors: matcha, sesame, tofu, and a seasonal option. The taiyaki is soft and crunchy at the same time; you'll definitely be smelling it the moment you walk through the main Japantown building entrance. Highly recommend the taiyaki if it's your first time - small size is more than enough. After that - I'd settle for the soft serve by itself. It is a little strange that the small serving of taiyaki comes with two toppings but the medium doesn't. Wouldn't it make sense to include toppings for both or neither? Hmm things to ponder.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
I had never had taiyaki before Uji Time, but now that I have, I can safely say that taiyaki is my favorite way to enjoy ice cream. The line is short, the turnaround from checkout to face-shoving is a minute at most, and hot damn that's some good ice cream!

I don't even like matcha as a flavor that much, so that makes this recommendation all the more glowing. The ice cream is just a little bit sweet, has a bold matcha flavor (of course), and is wonderfully creamy. It does melt fast, but you'll finish the whole thing before that becomes an issue! I highly recommend the chocolate sticks and Nutella, for whatever reason those chocolatey flavors complement the soft serve really well.

The taiyaki itself is freshly made shortly before you order, and it's like a waffle, but better. It's slightly sweet, like the ice cream itself, and does a good job of actually serving as a vehicle for the goods within by keeping together even after the bottom starts to melt. But it does so while still being deliciously soft, a feat of physics that will stump even the greatest engineers and scientists of our time. And the bottom is filled with Nutella or red bean paste, a sweet way to finish the experience.

Just go. You'll like it. Trust me.
author: Shawn W.

description: Uji Time has social media-worthy soft serves and cones, but the actual product is lacking. My friend recommended against getting the taiyaki cone for their matcha soft serve, but the waffle cone ended up being stale anyways. The matcha soft serve was a bit watered down in terms of flavor, and nothing close to the matcha soft serve flavor in Japan. The seasonal flavor during my visit was a sweet purple potato, which tasted a bit off. Much better ice cream options are to be had around the city so come if you must, take your picture, and move on.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Don't be irked by the long line--it's worth it IMO. I actually wish their taiyaki cones were even larger to fit more soft serve because I seriously wanted more after finishing my deluxe taiyaki (2 flavors and 2 toppings) w/ black sesame and tofu flavor soft serve, topped with green tea Pocky sticks and chocolate wafers. Request for one soft serve flavor on top of another, so you can relish each distinct flavor separately. Black sesame and tofu make a delicious combo. 

This legit scrumptious little simple treat isn't overwhelmingly sweet and you'll appreciate the contrast of the freshly baked, warm Japanese cake stuffed with sweet red bean paste and the cold, creamy soft serve. The batter of the taikyaki is thicker, so the cake is softer than the traditional crispy taikyaki. 

I only wish that the black sesame flavor was more prominent--I prefer a more rich, deep nutty taste. The one from here is pretty tame.

+ They also sell their soft serve in a cup or in a waffle cone, drinks, and ice cream mochi at this location
author: Merica S.

description:
I remember visiting Jtown a few months before Uji Time opened, not knowing this was actually going to be an Uji Time location. I went a few weeks ago and the line was out the door. No surprise there.

The first thing you'll realize is that long line of people. Don't turn around though and think "I'll go some other time". It's worth the wait! The second thing you'll notice is the wonderful aroma of fresh fish cones baking. Don't you dare think about leaving that line now!

I ordered a small matcha taiyaki with two pocky sticks and sprinkles. 

Yum. It was AMAZING. The ice cream was just right and not overwhelmingly sweet. As for the toppings, there are a number to choose from, so choose wisely. The pocky sticks were good (matcha flavored) but I should've chose the sprinkles that looked like sand (I think it was Azuki or Kinako) instead of the technicolor ones. The fish cone was soft, fresh and complemented the ice cream so well. And the red bean filling at the bottom of the cone is a great way to end this treat.

So if you're in Jtown and searching for some dessert, hit this place up because it's so worth it! Taiyaki doesn't disappoint.
author: Cassandra P.

description:
After an afternoon spent eating ramen and shopping at Daiso (Japanese version of the dollar store and way more fun), we opted for dessert. We hadn't wandered too far when we saw the line for this place and figured it must be good. (There are a number of other dessert places in this "mall" that I would like to try next time like nitrogen infused sweets but we didn't see these places till after Uji Time). 

This place is pretty straight forward. They serve four ice cream flavors and mochi. This trip we opted just for ice cream after trying a sample of each flavor. Options were black sesame, matcha, tofu (yes it tasted just like tofu) and their seasonal option, piña colada. We both went with piña colada flavor inside a fish cone (the whole reason I think most people come here is for the Instagram worthy photo they have with such unique ice cream). The ice cream is delicious though I was surprised how quickly it melted on a cold day. The cone is really soft so it felt like it would fall apart easily. Both of these reasons meant I devoured my treat faster than I would have liked. There is an assortment of toppings you can add but I felt like the ice cream didn't need much else so I opted for just the French cookie topping. Small comes with two toppings for free.
author: Tarah P.

description:
I had the matcha green tea in a taiyaki cone and it was pretty good! They ran out of mochi though ): 

The line was super long but my number came up fairly quick. Like right after I paid. 

The employees were okay. Didn't really seem like they liked their job but the desserts were good!
author: Erika N.

description:
I heard a lot of praise for this place, but after getting a chance to try it, I think it's just average at best.  Unfortunately, I don't think I would wait in their long lines to try it again.  

On a weekday afternoon around 3pm, I waited about 20 minutes to order.  I ordered a red bean filled taiyaki with matcha soft serve, and the most disappointing part was probably the soft serve.  The matcha flavor was very light, and the texture of the soft serve seemed a bit too much on the icy side for me.  The taiyaki pastry itself was pretty tasty, but mine was a bit cold, which seemed odd to me since they claim to make it all fresh.  

Overall though, I think it was a very OK dessert place that I would go to if the price and the wait times weren't so high.  Uji Time reminds me of the great taiyaki I've had elsewhere (ie. SomiSomi in Los Angeles), but it doesn't quite compare or hit the mark for me.
author: Tim L.

description:
I was hesitating between a 3 or a 4 here. If I have not eaten at Tokichi (made of match from Uji too) in Kyoto, I would tend to believe this was the best.

Four flavors to choose from - matcha, black sesame, tofu, and a special daily flavor. They also have three sizes and only the regular or deluxe would allow 2 flavors mix and match. Went with matcha and daily special (sweet corn), yet for some reason, it tasted too icy and less creamy (confirmed by my friend too). A bit disappointed here.

Super long line, so be prepared to wait for at least half an hour. Some of the ingredients ran out really quickly too. Currently in soft open mode, yet I do hope that they could keep up their inventories and speed up.
author: Elaine H.

description:
We caught them on their soft opening while exploring Japantown. I wasn't very hungry so I split a small taiyaki with my friend ($5.99 which comes with two toppings). I'm not usually a fan of matcha but Uji Time has surprisingly good matcha soft serve.

The taiyaki waffle itself tasted good. I was hoping it would af least be slightly crunchy but it wasn't. I still enjoyed it though :)

The line to order was long but it moves fast. They also give you pretty accurate estimated wait times (based on when you ordered) on the menu screen. I do wish they had more flavors available because I'm not a huge fan of either matcha or black sesame which were the only two they were serving the day I visited. 

Overall it was a pretty good first impression and I'm sure I'll be back when I'm in Japantown again :)
author: Marianne E.

description:
3.5 stars.

Had my eyes set on the large taiyaki with black sesame and matcha; unfortunately, they were out of matcha. Upon asking how long the matcha batch would take, the cashier told me it would take about 15-20 minutes because they'd need to make a new full one. I was not about to wait even longer, so I opted for the small taiyaki with black sesame, filled with red bean and topped with matcha powder and pocky sticks. I also got a sample of the tofu soft serve, which tasted like the soymilk you get at Chinese restaurants. 

My order was ready within minutes, though I did note that on their screen, they anticipated a wait time of 10+ minutes for the larger orders. In any case, the pocky sticks that accompanied my soft serve was green tea flavored, which I appreciated. The taiyaki was nice as crisp - also a good touch. I was most disappointed with the black sesame and red bean filling. The black sesame, although creamy in texture, was not flavorful enough for me; it was more of a subtle black sesame flavor. I prefer my black sesame soft serve to taste like black sesame; not a hint of it. The red bean filling was NOT a filling; it was more like half a teaspoon of red bean paste at the bottom of the taiyaki "cone". Also, make sure to eat more of the ice cream prior to biting into the "cone" or you'll have a liquid soft serve surprise streaming down your hand. In retrospect, I'm glad they ran out of the matcha because I don't think I would've been able to enjoy the soft serve as much, given that my small was already half melted by the time I got to the taiyaki portion. Would like to compare their matcha in the future, but definitely would not wait in line for it.
author: Leslie C.

description:
We came in on a Saturday morning right when they open. They already had a lot of people standing in line prior to opening. It took us about 20 minutes to order. 

I ordered the black sesame soft serve with taiyaki. The black sesame soft serve was awesome! Nice and rich! The taiyaki was a little too dry for me (maybe that's how it should be to prevent the taiyaki from getting soggy). Overall, soft serve was great. I may opt for a regular cone next time!
author: Yun Chi C.

description:
Smooth soft service, definitely a yes!

While waiting for ramen, my bf and I decided to try this place. We seen many instagram posts and was super curious! We got the Matcha Green tea with Taiyaki topped with French Crepe and Azuki (you get to choose 2 toppings for free). It was delicious, the soft serve was not overly sweet, just right and has a super matcha flavor. The Taiyaki was delicious and cripsy and chewy, as you bite down there is red bean inside! 

Overall, I would come back again and try their black sesame and tofu flavors!
author: Natalie L.

description:
Had to try this location to compare it to the Berkeley location!

An appropriate addition to Japan Town in SF. Although the wait might be long during peak hours, this place is definitely worth it to get your matcha soft-serve fix.

For $4 something, you get a HUGE proportion of matcha soft serve in a cup, waffle cone (YUM, I say this is the most worth option because you don't pay anymore for the waffle cone and it's huge, crunchy, and delicious), or Taiyaki fish cone (small vs large size). Do take note that if you get the infamous Taiyaki fish cone that you'll wait even longer because it takes around 10 mins. for the employees to actually make your cone since they're made fresh!

The two most important things for me when it comes to soft serve is of course the taste, but also the melting time. I disliked getting Uji Time at the Berkeley location because the majority of the time I went there, the soft serve melted quickly. However, at this SF Uji Time location, I have to say I was impressed with how well my matcha soft serve held up :) It seems like the proportions at the SF location is more too, as I found myself forcing myself to finish the soft serve to not waste the deliciousness. 

Very glad that there's a go-to matcha soft serve spot in SF ! Although parking around in this area is always a pain, there's now a forsure place to get your dessert fix after your yummy meal in this area.

RANDOM TIP: If you're like me and you can't decide on getting matcha or black sesame, definitely just get the swirl. Although the employee/cashier person might deter you away from that option because they say the black sesame overpowers the matcha, I say STICK WITH YOUR GUT because I wish I had. The employee talked me out of getting the black sesame swirled with the matcha and I definitely regretted it after I received my cone. I've had the combination of both flavors in a swirl before and if you try to eat both flavors at the same time, yes the black sesame will overpower the matcha. HOWEVER, if you just dip your spoon into each separate flavor of the swirl, you can definitely enjoy both flavors separately.

TLDR: I like this location better than Berkeley because for whatever reason, the matcha soft serve doesn't melt as quickly and it seems like the proportions are more (or maybe this just depends on the employee).
author: Jackie H.

description:
Meh.

Aesthetically pleasing does not equal pleasing the palate. 

I'm glad we came near closing cuz there was no line and I would've been irked if we had to wait the usual 40-75 minutes for this underwhelming, highly anticipated experience. 

I was really looking fwd to satisfying my taiyaki craving closer to home (vs JTSJ & JTLA). Sadly, Uji just didn't hit the spot. 

$16.50 & 10 minutes from order to service.
Not bad, right?

But what did that really get us at Uji?

2 Regular Taiyaki Cones ($6.99 each includes up to two flavors of the day) 
+ $0.50 per toppings (we opted for extra matcha powder). Pocky Sticks @ $0.50 each is robbery when Ichi Ban Kan / Daiso are next door & a whole box is $2 LMAO

Although the matcha green tea and black sesame were highly pigmented, the soft serve cream flavors were sadly lacking. TBH I would've been more content with that yogurt based Kirkland stuff sold at the Costco food court. 

The cashier chick was snippy but the person serving up at the pickup window was sweet. 

The crepe-battered taiyaki cone filled with azuki was Uji's saving grace.

It was 57°F (per Snapchat) last night and the cream could barely withstand walking a few yards to take the obligatory parasol mural pic in front of the East Mall entrance. 

By the time we got even a few yards further in front of the Peace Plaza, our taiyaki was taiYUCKY (insert super saiyan mad face). 

A runny, melted mess that we had to hurriedly lick n slurp n wooden-spoon-feed into our frowning mouths to avoid getting damn near $20 worth of cream-based liquid onto our KOTD's. 

Would I come back? Perhaps. Would I wait more than 15 mins, not likely. 

Still hunting for mind-blowing taiyaki in the area. Get at me if you can recommend your favorite spot (that isn't Uji! :)
author: Geminyna J.

description:
Small fish cone with red bean and green tea ice cream is worth the wait in line to order, and has practically zero wait time to pickup your order. 

I almost didn't come because I've been to the Berkeley location (which is not great --it pales in comparison to this Japantown Uji Time Dessert).

Glad we stopped by - very tasty!
author: Angie C.

description:
I waited at most 5 minutes for my fish cone lol because I miss the hype wait for everything (I'm the mouse who gets the cheese! heh) 

I had opt for the fish cone because it was the only cone to allow you two options of soft serve haha I love variety and the tofu flavor really got me curious - two ice creams and a fish cone is $6.99 if I rmb correctly 

both flavors were delicious! I love matcha already but the tofu one tasted very refreshing and very light also. if I come back I must get both. 

this is a lot of soft serve though - the matcha on the bottom filled the cone and the tofu on top was about 4in to 5in high, something to know if you're wanting to get one for urself haha I shared this and I was still having difficulty finishing

**what might deter me from coming back is for the 2 flavors you choose, they are stacked on top of one another versus combined into one large swirl - this makes sense why the board in front of the register said to only choose one flavor to enhance this experience.. cuz they don't got the two flavor one swirl option haha  another thing is our fish cone was cooked unevenly - the left side was a bit hard and the right side was ok, I guess the left side sat on the oven too long?

this will definitely be an option for me when I want dessert but not craving a drink. 75% will be back!
author: Yeanne L.

description:
Get the taiyaki cone with red bean filling (you get to choose between red bean and nutella filling)! I got the black sesame flavor which wasn't as strong as I'd like but still satisfied my black sesame craving. The small size is enough for two to share, so unless you have a lot of room for dessert, I'd suggest getting a small! Plus, you get to choose 2 free toppings with a small. The best part is the ending where you get to eat the yummy cone with the soft serve and filling! 

Tip: The ice cream will start to melt quickly since the fish cone is freshly made and super warm, so don't wait too long to devour everything.
author: Melody K.

description: Soft serve strawberry rose, fish cone with red bean filling. Always a little unsure about flavors like rose, and lavender because too much and they taste like potpourri and not enough and it's like what's the point. They did a good job here strawberry was the dominant flavor with a hint of rose. Cone was good and you can never go wrong with red bean filling, also liked how generous they were with the filling as some places tend to be a little stingy with it sometimes.
author: Heather L.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place and we were already around Japantown, so we decided to get. The service was quick and friendly! 

I tried the Black Sesame ice cream with a small Taiyaki cone and Pocky sticks (which are really Pejoy sticks, but still yummy). We all enjoyed what we got!
author: Elise F.

description:
What time is it? It's Uji Time! Haha, terrible HSM jokes aside, I was really excited to try this place. I've had a few taiyaki ice cream cones in socal, but this is the first time I got to try one in norcal! Unfortunately, I don't make my way to Berkeley too often. 

San Francisco's Uji Time took over the spot in Japantown's mall that used to house the cotton candy milk tea establishment, next to the bridge. It's a tiny, tiny store, and only has room for literally maybe three customers at a  time with no seats at all, so you can imagine that the line was a little ridiculously long. Nevertheless, I was determined to try it out. The line actually moves fairly fast, and they also have a wait time posted on their digital screens iterating how long it would be until the next batch of taiyaki cones would be ready. The cones come in two sizes: mini and regular, and I got the mini! It's definitely still sizable for a "mini," and my stomach was satisfied post-consumption.

What I Ordered:
-Matcha Small Taiyaki (3/5): The ice cream had a moderately strong matcha flavor, and I really enjoyed how they sprinkle matcha powder on the top of the ice cream. The ice cream itself was alright...it wasn't the best matcha ice cream I've had. The cone itself was pretty tasty, and paired well with the red bean at the bottom, as well as the ice cream.  

-Matcha Chocolate Chip Mochi (4/5): Okay, I got this for the 'gram, but this was actually very tasty. Props.

Warning: The cone is VERY messy to eat. I'm usually not a fan of messy foods that are sticky (i.e. I avoid chicken wings like the plague if I can), so this was a full-on panic situation for me. It wasn't a noticeably warm day in SF, but my ice cream started melting within a minute flat. Grab napkins! It dripped all over the place, and by the time I got to the bottom, it was just an unrecognizable mess of ice cream, soggy cone, and red bean. 

The customer service was good! They offer samples of the ice cream if you're unsure of what flavor your want! I sampled the tofu flavor, which I've never, ever had in ice cream form before. It was pretty tasty, but I'm a slave to anything matcha-flavored so I still ordered the matcha. Maybe I'll get the tofu next time!
author: Stephanie N.

description: A+ for concept, but I wasn't totally sold on this. After seeing so many photos of Uji Time on IG, I knew I had to stop here. I love traditional taiyaki, and I love Japanese soft cream. To blend the two together is genius. But, unfortunately, I didn't love my taiyaki "cone" and felt like the ice cream was just OK. The taiyaki was a wilted when it came off the iron (although I was told that the regular sized version is pre-made rather than made to order), and the matcha ice cream was definitely matcha-y but not the same buttery creaminess Japanese soft cream usually is. While it's great for the 'gram, I'm not sure I'd brave a long line to try this again.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Uji Time is all about the expectations so Set then accordingly. I came during their soft opening on vacation, and it's conveniently located in the Japan Center (East.)

It's a bit on the pricier side if you order the Taiyaki soft cream small or large sizes. If you've never had Taiyaki, it's basically a pancake/waffle batter poured into a fish mold.

Otherwise, $3.99 for matcha, black sesame, or tofu flavored soft cream cones is a nice treat to enjoy with friends or your partner. The soft cream is nice and airy, with small bit of ice texture with the tofu, sesame, and matcha showing restraint in flavor. Not overpowering as one would think.

Uji Time also have multiple types of mochi ice cream, but the lychee pina colada was my favorite! Great texture in the skin and the ice cream part of it was well balanced.

Expect lines, but enjoy this nice treat. I wish we had one of these in Chicago, but I'll gladly enjoy Uji Time on my vacation!
author: Daniel Y.

description: BEST Mochi EVER!!!! Creamy, rich, delicious. There's always a wait, but it goes fast.
author: Sara M.

description:
My friends and I finally made our way to Uji Time after slurping down some udon in Japantown. We've heard about the line but luckily it wasn't too crowded when we arrived on a Wednesday night. 

My friend and I split the regular size taiyaki with green tea soft serve ($7). We originally wanted two mini sizes but the wait time was 45+ minutes for those, whereas the wait time for the regular was 25+ minutes. I'm glad we shared because it was actually a pretty good portion size for 3 people (our other friend had some as well). 

We chatted while waiting and around 20 minutes later, we got our order!! The green tea soft serve exceeded our expectations. It wasn't too sweet and it also wasn't too bitter either. We were super excited to get to the taiyaki fish cone because we had never tried it before. It was basically like eggettes batter in a fish shape! It had soft insides with a nice crunch on the edges. There was also red bean on the bottom of the fish, probably to try to avoid spillage. I'm not a big red bean fan, but it tasted good with the green tea soft serve! 

I would probably come back if I were in the area but wouldn't go out of my way to try this. It was a good first-time experience though!
author: Tara A.

description:
Tofu flavored ice cream!!!!! Such a weird, yet satisfying flavor. I love tofu and didn't know what to expect. I've never been to a soft serve place with that flavor. To my surprise it actually taste just like tofu. For those of you who aren't big tofu eaters, it could be a little plain for some. However they have both matcha and black sesame as well. 

The taiyaki soft serve concept has made its way to SF. Not the best taiyaki I've ever had but at least it was an attempt. Taiyaki itself is probably a 2 star, but everything together brings it up. Just not a comparison to Taiyaki NYC. The wait as well was not worth it for a larger size. Hopefully once they become a little more popular they can get rid of some bottlenecks in the operation (sorry for the business terms).
author: Justin Y.

description: Get here early (10 mins before opening) as the lines will get super long. I really enjoyed the black sesame flavor and got a regular cone. I thought the quality of their ingredients was high and I hope tit stays that way. It was the perfect blend of icy and cream for me. My friend got the tofu flavor and didn't not find it creamy enough.
author: Lily P.

description:
We came to Japantown for some bubble tea but I LOVE ice cream and could not resist trying Uji Time when we saw it was their soft opening! The was out the door and about 10ft down the hall but moved pretty quickly. 

Since we had a pretty substantial lunch, my fiance and I split a small Taiyaki cone ($5.99) which included 1 ice cream flavor and 2 toppings. Although there was a long line, the cashier was very patient and helpful when we asked for clarification on the topping choices. We chose matcha ice cream with azuki (red bean paste) and Pocky sticks, and we loved everything about it! The matcha soft serve was smooth and flavorful and the Taiyaki cone came out warm and fluffy. 

I really like that their menu sign also mentions how long you can expect to wait for the Taiyaki cones to be done. When we ordered, the sign said +5 mins for the small Taiyaki but it was actually done even sooner. 

We also were able to try a sample of the seasonal flavor, but I'm not sure that I'm a fan of corn soft serve... However, I would highly recommend both the matcha and black sesame!
author: Janice L.

description:
Oh man! Where do I begin. Keep seeing matcha soft serve, mochi and poky sticks in fish waffle cones on Instagram, and have been DYING to get my hands on them. I wasn't disappointed in the least! This place smells AMAZING, and it tastes even better. We were all set on getting the matcha, but we ended up trying black sesame as well. The matcha was good, strong tea flavor, etc, but honestly, the black sesame ended up being surprisingly even better! It was sweet, and it was strong. It tasted exactly like those sweet roasted sesame drinks. Eating the matcha right after a taste of the black sesame one will make the matcha taste bland like water. It was seriously make you regret getting the matcha! 

With the black sesame, totally recommend the azuki (red bean paste) and kinako (peanut butter powder), they really compliment the black sesame flavor. With the matcha, you really can choose any toppings without going wrong, but we were all pretty disappointed with the mochi. 

It can totally get messy, but oh man it is so worth it. Biting into the fish cone is the BEST, and at the tail end of the fish (literally), you get a surprise red bean paste tucked in. SO GOOD. 

I think the deluxe and regular size is the same size, you just get more toppings with the deluxe. Those sizes are great for sharing, but if you want your own, I think the small size is perfect.
author: Ke C.

description:
It was everything I had hoped for. We arrived at 8:40pm to a short line. I was nervously excited. He probably thought I was overly enthusiastic about fish-shaped ice cream but I appreciate that he went along with it anyway. We watched in envy as others got their ice cream.

When we got to the front of the line, I asked for samples and the girl gave us one of each (matcha, sesame, tofu, and the seasonal lavender). I liked both matcha and sesame and we decided on the matcha. The line was moving slowly not because they could not make taiyaki cones fast enough but because samples take too long (the soft serve machines are located too far away from the cashier).

We got our regular matcha taiyaki ice cream and in true Asian fashion, I spent a good amount of time positioning the prized ice cream to optimize the photo. It's a lot harder than it looks (where are you supposed to put your hand?)

I like the matcha flavor and the relatively soft texture of the cone. A sweet surprise of red bean awaited us when we got down toward the bottom. Sharing one regular taiyaki ice cream was the perfect size for the two of us. And if you don't take as much time trying to capture a photo, you might be able to avoid the messy melting ice cream situation we found ourselves in at the end.
author: Yi Z.

description:
I don't normally think that waiting in line for dessert is ever justified - but it was worth it here at Uji Time.

Their green tea and black sesame soft serve are so flavor forward you can tell they're using the good matcha and not skimping out. It's really really delicious and I think the only thing that made it better is the taiyaki (fish) cone with red bean on the inside. So once you're done licking your soft serve, you're treated with the soft doughy taiyaki and semi-sweet red bean filling.

What I love about japanese desserts, and especially at Uji, is that everything just has a hint of sweetness and it's not overwhelming. Just so so so perfect.

This is the good stuff. At around $7 for a basic version + taiyaki, t's almost half the price of your bowl of ramen. But it's so worth it dude.
author: Sally L.

description:
Surprisingly, better than expected. I mean, yes, I did find this place bc it's popping up all over every food account on instagram. I'm not a huge fan of waffles, bready situations and usually just get ice creams or yogurts or gelato or whatever it is. But I figured if I came all the way here, I mind as well try the special fishy cone. 

First of all, if you're wondering where it is...you can't miss it. There's a huge line wrapping around outside of the shop. Their tv menu actually shows wait times for their small and large fishy cones. It's a really nice touch to help you get a better understanding of ETA. 

There's four flavors. The 3 standards are: matcha, tofu and sesame. The seasonal one rn is honey lavender. I really wasn't sure which flavor to get, but tried all the flavors w my friends when we got to the front. I love me some floral flavors (ie Jasmine Tea), but the honey lavender didn't taste right for this situation. Even more surprisingly, the tofu one was the best! Tastes just like the Chinese tofu dessert, if you've ever had that before. Also, I honestly thought that the fishy waffle would get soggy frm the ice cream, but it didn't! They definitely hold up really well. Plus there's a red bean surprise at the bottom of the waffle!

All in all, I was pleasantly surprised by how much I liked the ice cream and waffle here. The girl behind the register was also super calm and accommodating, letting us try all the flavors even tho there's a pretty long line. Would def come back another time! 5 stars :)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Super long wait but pretty good matcha soft serve! It's not overly sweet and it has a strong tea flavor to it.
